visibility_factors: freezing fog potential late evening (around 11 PM)
periodic very low visibility readings overnight/late evening (0–1 mi reported in hourly data)

alert_summary.description: Very cold wind chills as low as 20 to 25 below expected Friday morning; in effect from 1 AM Friday to 10 AM Saturday.
Dangerously cold wind chills as low as 25 below possible late Thursday night through Saturday morning (watch status).
Advisory focused on snow/wind impacts through Thursday (Jan 22); not indicating additional snow on Friday in this dataset.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Friday 2026-01-23 in Rockford, MI, the primary hazard is extreme cold (air temps near/below 0°F by evening and wind chills roughly -15°F to -27°F during the daytime, colder at times overnight). No accumulating snow is forecast (0"), so this is not a classic Michigan snow-day setup. Winds are modest (NW ~10–18 mph) but sufficient to produce dangerous wind chills. The main school-impact risk is cold-related (bus stops, exposed skin) and potential localized freezing fog/near-zero visibility late evening/overnight; however, the worst visibility signals occur outside the typical morning commute window in this dataset. Overall: low snow-day probability from snowfall, but moderate risk of delays/closures driven by extreme wind chills and any patchy dense freezing fog.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Arctic high pressure / cold-dry day: no accumulating snow, but daytime temps near 0–5°F with steady NW wind (10–20 mph) producing wind chills in the -10°F to -25°F range during the morning commute. These setups historically produce delays/closures only when a district uses a strict wind-chill policy or when transportation risk is high for walkers/bus stops.

Post-lake-effect / post-advisory hangover: prior-day light snow/freezing precip with gusty winds, followed by a sharp temperature crash overnight. Even with little/no new snow on the target day, refreeze of slush + residual drifting in open rural areas can create isolated hazardous spots early (bridges, overpasses, country roads). Closures are more likely if the previous evening had untreated wet roads that freeze hard by dawn.

Radiational cooling + freezing fog late evening: clear/light wind at night with temps falling below -5°F to -15°F and fog/freezing fog developing. This can create surprise “black ice” and near-zero visibility pockets, but typically impacts late-night travel more than the school morning commute unless fog persists past sunrise.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in West Michigan is prime for lake-effect variability, but school closures in Rockford/Kent County are most commonly driven by (1) heavy snow at the wrong time (overnight into pre-dawn) and/or (2) ice. A cold, mostly dry day by itself is usually not enough unless wind chills are extreme or roads refreeze after prior precipitation.
unusual_factors: Very cold air mass for the date with forecast highs around 5°F and lows near -14°F.
Wind chills near the Thursday night/Friday morning period appear capable of approaching the -20°F to -25°F range (consistent with the Cold Weather Advisory timing).
No new snow is forecast for Friday (0.0"), shifting the closure risk away from plowing capacity and toward cold exposure and refreeze/spot-ice risk.

local_microclimates: Kent County commonly sees lake-effect bands and sharp visibility changes, but Friday’s forecast profile is cold/dry—microclimate differences matter more for leftover drifting and localized slick spots than for new accumulation.
Rural edges and open corridors north and west of Rockford can see more drifting/packed snow issues than the denser core roads, especially after a windy advisory period.
infrastructure_considerations: Michigan districts often remain open through moderate snow if roads are plowed; closures more often follow ice, whiteout conditions, or extreme cold that makes bus-stop exposure unsafe.
Bridges/overpasses and shaded secondary roads are the main hazard Friday given the hard freeze following Thursday’s wintry precip.
If your district has many walkers or long bus waits, the wind-chill-driven risk increases relative to snow-amount-driven risk.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford is not a major elevation-driven snow microclimate, but small terrain and open-field exposures can enhance drifting and wind chill on rural routes; the bigger driver here is arctic cold plus any refreeze.

history.confidence_assessment: For Friday 2026-01-23, the forecast shows no new snow, but a significant arctic cold day (high ~5°F, low ~-14°F) with morning wind chills around the mid -teens to possibly near -20°F or lower. In Michigan, that pattern alone usually yields a LOW-to-MODERATE closure probability; the most plausible triggers would be (a) wind chill policy thresholds being met around the morning commute and/or (b) widespread refreeze/black ice from Thursday’s freezing precip/snow. If roads are treated and wind chill stays above local closure thresholds, expect normal operations; if wind chills verify near -25°F at bus time or refreeze is widespread, odds of a delay/closure rise. Overall confidence: medium, with the biggest uncertainty being how much untreated moisture remains to refreeze and how low the wind chills get at 6–8 AM.

safety_recommendations: Primary operational risk is extreme cold/wind chill during bus-stop wait times (roughly 06:00–08:00). Consider adding/using heated indoor waiting options where feasible and minimizing outdoor exposure time.
Even with no new snow expected Friday, anticipate slick spots from refreeze of Thursday’s wintry precip—especially bridges/overpasses, shaded curves, rural two-tracks, and subdivision streets.
Have road crews spot-treat known icy locations before 05:30–06:00; salt effectiveness is reduced in single-digit °F temperatures, so prioritize abrasives/sand and targeted treatments.
Expect reduced visibility in pockets (some hours report near-zero vis in the feed). Use caution for bus routing; allow extra following distance and reduce speeds on secondary roads.
Run buses with cold-weather contingencies: verify block heaters/fuel additives, keep radios charged, and plan for longer warm-up/door-cycle times.
For students walking: require full winter gear (face covering, gloves, insulated boots). Frostbite risk increases quickly with wind chills near/below -20°F.

local_news.source: Big Rapids News (winter weather advisory coverage)
local_news.headline: Winter Weather Advisory mentions Kent County; lake-effect snow may persist through Friday with dangerous cold possible
local_news.summary: A winter weather advisory story covering multiple West/Central Michigan counties explicitly lists Kent County among the impacted areas, with discussion of accumulating snow, slippery travel, and the possibility of lake-effect snow lingering into Friday plus dangerous subzero temps/wind chills later in the week. This is a broad regional signal rather than a Rockford-specific closure notice, but it supports elevated snow-day risk for Fri 2026-01-23 if the colder/windier conditions and continued snow materialize overnight.

local_news.source: FOX 17 West Michigan – Closings & Delays page
local_news.headline: FOX 17 closings page shows many weather-related cancellations (mostly activities/organizations) dated Jan 21–22, 2026
local_news.summary: FOX 17’s closings/delays feed shows a notable number of weather-related cancellations/early releases for organizations and at least one district activity adjustment (example: Belding Area Public Schools early release/no evening activities listed on Jan 22). While this is not a definitive indicator for Rockford Public Schools on Fri 1/23, the volume of cancellations is a ‘background’ signal that weather impacts are already prompting schedule changes in the region.

local_news.headline: WMU closed campuses on Jan. 22, 2026 due to severe weather (and also closed Jan. 20, 2026)
local_news.summary: WMU posted that it closed all campuses and canceled classes on Jan 22, 2026 due to severe weather (and also had a closure on Jan 20, 2026). University closures don’t guarantee K-12 closures, but they are a strong regional severity signal that conditions have been disruptive in West Michigan this week leading into Friday 1/23.

local_news.headline: School-closings outlook for Wed 01/21, Thu 01/22, Fri 01/23 discusses snow totals/rates and closure likelihood zones
local_news.summary: A local weather blog posted a school-closings outlook spanning Wed 1/21 through Fri 1/23, describing expected snowfall totals and higher snowfall-rate corridors that could complicate the morning commute. This is not an official source, but it’s relevant as a ‘chatter/forecast’ signal that people are actively evaluating closure potential for Fri 1/23.

official_announcements: Rockford Public Schools (Rockford, MI) district homepage ‘Announcements & Closings’ did not show a weather-related closure/delay announcement for Friday, 2026-01-23 at time of check (most recent items were non-weather updates).

reported_road_conditions: Reddit r/grandrapids thread (Jan 19, 2026) references hazardous conditions, plow catch-up, concerns about black ice, and cites a large multi-vehicle pileup as context; commenters also note that side roads/bus routes matter even when main roads look OK.
local_event_cancellations: FOX 17 closings feed shows multiple Kent-area churches/organizations canceling evening activities on Jan 21–22, 2026 (indicative of ongoing weather disruption).

news.key_findings_summary: For Rockford, Michigan (Rockford Public Schools) specifically, I did not find a direct, official closure/delay announcement yet for Friday, 2026-01-23 on the district’s main ‘Announcements & Closings’ area at the time of this scan. However, there are several regional severity signals leading into Friday: (1) broad-area winter weather coverage that includes Kent County and mentions snow plus dangerous cold lingering into Friday; (2) a high volume of cancellations/adjustments appearing on West Michigan closings pages; and (3) institutional closures like WMU (Jan 20 and Jan 22, 2026) suggesting this week’s conditions have been significant. Community chatter (notably on r/grandrapids) is focused on hazardous travel, especially untreated side roads and potential black ice—factors that often drive bus-route-based decisions. Net: no confirmed Rockford Friday closure yet, but the ‘risk backdrop’ for a snow day/delay on Fri 1/23 appears elevated if overnight snow/ice and extreme wind chills persist.

primary_factors: No accumulating snow forecast Friday (0") — removes the primary Michigan closure trigger
Dangerous cold: NWS Cold Weather Advisory; 6–9 AM wind chills forecast roughly -12°F to -15°F (cold, but not in the ≤ -20°F near-guarantee tier)
Patchy refreeze/black-ice risk from prior-day wintry precip, mainly on secondary roads/bridges/parking lots; salt effectiveness reduced in single digits
Visibility/fog risk appears minimal during 6–9 AM (forecast ~6 mi); worst dense/freezing fog signals are overnight/late evening
No confirmed weather-related closures for Rockford or nearby districts at time of check (neighboring closure found was non-weather related)

timeline.peak_impact_time: 2026-01-23 06:00–08:30 (cold exposure + patchy ice risk during bus/commute window)
timeline.conditions_improve: 2026-01-23 09:00–12:00 (still very cold, but daylight and traffic improve visibility/traction; afternoon impacts minimal)

final.decision_rationale:
PRE-DECISION CHECKLIST:
1) AGREEMENT: All experts agree Friday is a cold-driven day with essentially no new snow; main risks are wind chill exposure and patchy refreeze/black ice. Also agreement that a delay is more plausible than a full closure.
2) DISAGREEMENT: News sources suggested snow might linger into Friday regionally, but the meteorological dataset/hours show 0% precip and good 6–9 AM visibility; I weight the explicit hourly forecast higher. Visibility “0 mi” readings look confined to overnight/late evening rather than commute time.
3) Plow timing math: If Thu operations wrap ~19:00, there are ~12h40m until a 07:40 start (and ~11h until ~06:00 first pickups). Even if final spot-treat starts ~23:00, there are ~8h40m to 07:40 (~7h to 06:00). Best window is ~03:30–05:30 for fresh treatment. This supports manageability absent new snow.
4) ANY ice? Yes, but likely patchy not widespread: moderate refreeze risk (bridges, shaded secondaries, lots). Salt is less effective in single digits, so abrasives/targeting matter; this raises delay odds more than full-closure odds.
5) Neighboring districts: No confirmed weather-related closures/delays for Rockford or listed neighbors at time checked; one neighboring closure (Northview) was for a non-weather reason, so no +15–20% “wave” adjustment.
6) What would make me WRONG? (a) Wind chills verify closer to -20°F to -25°F at 6–8 AM (policy-trigger territory), (b) refreeze proves widespread on bus routes (not patchy), or (c) an unmodeled lake-effect band/visibility crash develops pre-dawn.

WEIGHTED SYNTHESIS (per system weights):
- Meteorology (30%): cold advisory but 6–9 AM wind chill ~-12 to -15 and no snow; lowers closure probability.
- Safety (20% incl. infra/power): moderate patchy ice + extreme cold exposure; supports some chance of delay/closure.
- History (15%): cold-only closures are uncommon unless thresholds met; antecedent refreeze can drive “sneaky delay.”
- News intel (15%): no confirmed closure wave; reduces odds.

Given Michigan thresholds and lack of snow/ice storm signals, I set full snow-day/closure probability at 23% (leaning ‘open, possible delay’ rather than ‘closed’).

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Winds a bit stronger and temps a bit lower than forecast; wind chills at/under -20°F for multiple hours during pickups
alternative_scenarios.impact: Delay or cold-based closure becomes much more likely (bus-stop exposure risk dominates).

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Refreeze is widespread on secondary roads/bridges and multiple bus routes report slick travel by ~05:30–06:00
alternative_scenarios.impact: 2-hour delay likely; isolated areas could push toward closure if treatment can’t keep up in single-digit temps.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Forecast verifies as expected: good visibility 6–9 AM, roads mostly dry/treated with only isolated slick spots
alternative_scenarios.impact: School open; at most minor route adjustments and increased cold-safety protocols.

for_schools: Plan for OPEN with enhanced cold protocols; be prepared to pivot to a 2-hour delay if route checks find widespread slick spots by ~05:30–06:00.
Run early-morning verification loops on known trouble spots (bridges/ramps, shaded subdivisions, rural edges) and require drivers to report traction/visibility in real time.
Mitigate cold exposure: minimize outdoor wait times, allow early building entry where possible, and message families about face/hand protection.
for_residents: Dress for dangerous wind chills at stops (cover exposed skin; limit wait time).
Assume patchy black ice on neighborhood streets/bridges; slow down and increase following distance even if main roads look fine.
Start vehicles early; keep emergency cold kit/blanket in car.
for_authorities: Spot-treat bridges, hills, curves, and stop-controlled approaches with abrasives/sand; don’t rely on salt alone in single digits.
Prioritize 03:30–05:30 treatment window to be freshest for 06:00–08:00 travel.
Push clear public messaging: ‘cold + patchy ice’ rather than ‘snowstorm’ to reduce complacency.

positions.rationale: For Friday, Jan 23, 2026 in Rockford, MI, the forecast is a classic arctic, mostly-dry day: extremely cold but with no additional accumulation. In most Michigan districts, that usually does NOT produce a full closure unless wind chills hit district thresholds and/or there’s a secondary hazard (widespread refreeze/black ice or persistent dense freezing fog at bus time). Given the explicit Cold Weather Advisory timing (1 AM Fri–10 AM Sat) and modeled wind chills approaching -25°F Friday morning, I put meaningful but still sub-50% odds on a closure; however, with 0" new snow forecast, my baseline stays on the low-to-moderate side. Net: more likely ‘open (maybe a delay)’ than ‘closed.’
keyFactors: No new precip expected Friday (0" snow; 0% precip chances). That removes the #1 driver of K-12 closures (plowing/whiteout/ice accretion during the commute).

Extreme cold is the main hazard: air temps around 5°F late morning with a plunge toward ~-14°F overnight; wind chills roughly -20°F to -27°F during the day and near bus-stop time (6–9 AM). This can trigger cold/wind-chill policy closures in some districts.

Wind is noticeable but not blizzard-grade: sustained ~10–18 mph with gusts ~20–26 mph early. Enough for dangerous wind chill, but not enough (by itself) for blowing/drifting shutdowns without falling snow.

Visibility flags are the wildcard: multiple hourly entries show 0–1 mile/0 km visibility, and “freezing fog” appears late evening. If dense freezing fog or low stratus persists into 6–8 AM, that can create a localized delay/closure scenario even without snow.

“Post-event” risk: Thursday’s winter weather advisory implies prior snow/ice and gusts. With a hard freeze overnight, any residual moisture/slush can refreeze into black ice on secondary roads/bridges before treatment is effective in single-digit temps.

positions.rationale: From a historical/operations perspective, Rockford/Kent-area closures are most strongly tied to heavy snow timing and ice. Friday’s forecast is atypical: extreme cold without new snow. That shifts the decision to policy thresholds (wind chill) and transportation safety (refreeze on secondary roads). Given (1) no accumulating snow forecast Friday, (2) cold advisories indicating potentially hazardous wind chills during the morning commute, and (3) the likelihood of some refreeze after Thursday’s wintry precip, I land in a **low–moderate** closure range. I’m setting **22%** as the probability of a *full snow day/closure* (with a higher implied probability of a *delay* than a full closure).
keyFactors: **Cold-driven operations (not snow-driven):** Friday 2026-01-23 has *0" new snow forecast* but very low temps (high ~5°F, low ~-14°F) and wind chills that get into the **-20°F to -25°F** territory during the morning hours (supported by the Cold Weather Advisory timing). Districts historically close for cold less often than for snow/ice—so this raises risk, but usually into the *delay/limited* zone unless thresholds are clearly exceeded.

**“Hangover” risk from Thursday’s event:** A Winter Weather Advisory is active Thursday (Jan 22) and the region has active disruptions. Even if precip ends, the sharp temperature drop means **refreeze of slush/treated meltwater** and **residual drifting/packed snow** on secondary/rural roads can matter more than the clean Friday forecast. Historically, these setups produce *some* closures, but more commonly isolated slick spots and a few delays.

**Morning-commute specificity:** The most decision-relevant window is **~6–8 AM Friday**. If wind chills verify closer to -25°F *at bus-stop time* (and/or if freezing fog/visibility issues occur near sunrise rather than late evening), closure odds jump. If conditions are “just very cold” with decent visibility and treated roads, many MI districts stay open.

**Institutional/behavioral backdrop:** Regional cancellations/closures earlier in the week (per News agent) suggest heightened sensitivity and possible staffing/transport strain; that can slightly increase the chance of a Friday closure even without fresh snow.

positions.rationale: From a safety/operations standpoint, Friday (2026-01-23) looks like a *cold-driven* risk day rather than a snow-driven one. The forecast indicates extremely cold morning wind chills (dangerous for students waiting at stops and for walkers), but there is no accumulating snow expected Friday, and winds are not at blizzard/whiteout levels. That combination typically produces either normal operations or a *delay* rather than a full closure—unless the district has explicit wind-chill closure thresholds or visibility/black-ice becomes more widespread than expected. Given the data, I put closure probability in the low-to-moderate range rather than high.
keyFactors: **Primary safety driver is extreme cold, not snow:** Friday AM wind chills are in the dangerous range (roughly -15°F to -27°F in the hourly data), aligning with the Cold Weather Advisory timing (1 AM Fri–10 AM Sat). That can trigger cold-exposure operational decisions (bus stops, walkers), but many districts still operate unless thresholds are stricter or compounded by other hazards.
**No new snow forecast Friday (0") lowers classic closure odds:** With precip and snowfall at/near zero, the usual “can we plow in time?” driver is absent.

**Refreeze/black-ice risk is plausible but not clearly “widespread” from the data:** Thursday includes wintry precip/snow (and an advisory). A sharp temperature drop into single digits/subzero increases the chance of residual moisture refreezing on bridges, shaded roads, and untreated subdivision/rural segments—more likely to cause *isolated* hazards and perhaps a delay than a full closure.

**Visibility anomalies are a wildcard:** The hourly feed reports several near-zero visibility values overnight/early morning despite no precip, and “freezing fog” appears late evening. If dense fog/freezing fog were to coincide with the bus window (roughly 6–8 AM), that would materially increase closure/delay odds. Right now, it’s not clearly centered on the commute window.
**Road treatment effectiveness reduced:** In single digits/subzero, salt effectiveness drops; if crews are behind from Thursday’s event, untreated spots become more consequential for buses.

positions.rationale:
From a news/operations standpoint, the strongest “go/no-go” indicator would be an official Rockford Public Schools announcement or a wave of neighboring K-12 districts preemptively closing for Fri 2026-01-23. We don’t have that here. The local-news items mostly describe broader west/central Michigan impacts and activity cancellations tied to Thu 1/22 conditions, which can create a perception that Friday is a high-closure day.

However, the actual Friday forecast in the provided dataset is cold and dry with no accumulating snow expected. That usually shifts decisions to (a) wind-chill policy thresholds and (b) whether refreeze/black ice is widespread enough to disrupt bus routes. Given the advisory timing and the potential for untreated surfaces to refreeze hard, I land on a low-to-moderate probability overall—closer to “possible delay” than “likely full closure.”
keyFactors: No new precip forecast for Fri 2026-01-23 (0" snow / 0" liquid) makes a full snow day less likely than the “news noise” might suggest.

Cold is the main operational hazard: air temps in the single digits (high ~5°F) with morning wind chills roughly around -15°F to -25°F range (Cold Weather Advisory window 1 AM Fri–10 AM Sat). This raises risk for a *delay* more than a closure, especially for long bus-stop exposure.

“Post-event hangover” risk: Thursday’s snow/freezing precip + falling temps can refreeze slush into black ice on side streets, bridges, and rural bus routes. Even without new snow, this can push districts toward a 2-hour delay if conditions are widespread at 5–7 AM.

Visibility flags in the hourly feed (some 0 mi readings; freezing fog noted late) introduce a small tail risk—if dense fog/freezing fog lingers into early morning, travel safety concerns could escalate quickly.

News/operational backdrop: regional cancellations and WMU closure on Thu 2026-01-22 signal this week has been disruptive, but they’re not deterministic for Rockford Public Schools on Fri 2026-01-23; no Rockford-specific Friday closure announcement found in the provided news scan.

From a safety/operations standpoint, Friday (2026-01-23) looks like a *cold-driven* risk day rather than a snow-driven one. The forecast indicates extremely cold morning wind chills (dangerous for students waiting at stops and for walkers), but there is no accumulating snow expected Friday, and winds are not at blizzard/whiteout levels. That combination typically produces either normal operations or a *delay* rather than a full closure—unless the district has explicit wind-chill closure thresholds or visibility/black-ice becomes more widespread than expected. Given the data, I put closure probability in the low-to-moderate range rather than high.

From a news/operations standpoint, the strongest “go/no-go” indicator would be an official Rockford Public Schools announcement or a wave of neighboring K-12 districts preemptively closing for Fri 2026-01-23. We don’t have that here. The local-news items mostly describe broader west/central Michigan impacts and activity cancellations tied to Thu 1/22 conditions, which can create a perception that Friday is a high-closure day.

However, the actual Friday forecast in the provided dataset is cold and dry with no accumulating snow expected. That usually shifts decisions to (a) wind-chill policy thresholds and (b) whether refreeze/black ice is widespread enough to disrupt bus routes. Given the advisory timing and the potential for untreated surfaces to refreeze hard, I land on a low-to-moderate probability overall—closer to “possible delay” than “likely full closure.”

keyDisagreements.topic: Some cited ‘risk backdrop’ signals (regional cancellations, a local blog mentioning lake-effect lingering into Friday) conflict with the provided hour-by-hour forecast showing 0% snow chances Friday. I’d weight the explicit hourly precip/temps higher for the Fri decision, unless we see updated model guidance indicating lake-effect redevelopment.
positions: Some cited ‘risk backdrop’ signals (regional cancellations, a local blog mentioning lake-effect lingering into Friday) conflict with the provided hour-by-hour forecast showing 0% snow chances Friday. I’d weight the explicit hourly precip/temps higher for the Fri decision, unless we see updated model guidance indicating lake-effect redevelopment.

keyDisagreements.topic: The safety window (06:00–08:00) makes sense, but the near-zero visibility readings in the hourly feed are inconsistent (0 km at times with no precip) and occur at several non-commute hours too; we should treat that as ‘possible patchy fog/low stratus’ rather than guaranteed widespread whiteout. Overstating visibility certainty could inflate closure odds.
positions: The safety window (06:00–08:00) makes sense, but the near-zero visibility readings in the hourly feed are inconsistent (0 km at times with no precip) and occur at several non-commute hours too; we should treat that as ‘possible patchy fog/low stratus’ rather than guaranteed widespread whiteout. Overstating visibility certainty could inflate closure odds.

keyDisagreements.topic: The historical closure rates cited (0.12–0.18) are plausible, but the ‘cold-only’ closure probability is highly policy-dependent. If Rockford Public Schools has a strict wind-chill threshold (e.g., around -20°F to -25°F), the probability could be materially higher than historical averages; without that policy detail, we should avoid anchoring too hard to past rates.
positions: The historical closure rates cited (0.12–0.18) are plausible, but the ‘cold-only’ closure probability is highly policy-dependent. keyDisagreements.topic: Your visibility section flags several hours with **0 mi** visibility readings, but many of those appear outside the core commute window and may reflect feed artifacts. Can you isolate the most plausible **6–9 AM** visibility/fog risk (persistence past sunrise) vs. late-evening freezing fog? This materially affects closure odds.

keyDisagreements.topic: You rate ice risk as ‘moderate’ and note salt effectiveness issues in single digits (true), but the forecast shows **0 precip Friday** and winds not extreme. Can you clarify whether you’re assuming **wet roads Thursday evening** (leading to widespread refreeze) vs. mostly dry roads after plowing? The assumed *extent* of refreeze is the biggest swing factor.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 21 at 9:22PM EST until January 22 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Oceana; Newaygo; Muskegon; Ottawa; Kent; Allegan; Barry; Van Buren; Kalamazoo
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations tonight between 2 and 5
inches, and an additional 1 to 3 on Thursday. Winds gusting as
high as 35 mph.

* WHERE...Portions of southwest and west central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST Thursday.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions
may change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow. Plan
on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact
the Thursday morning and evening commutes.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Extreme Cold Watch issued January 21 at 9:22PM EST until January 24 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton; Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Dangerously cold wind chills as low as 25 below possible.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest, and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...From late Thursday night through Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 25 below zero
could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.
Frostbite and hypothermia will occur if unprotected skin is
exposed to these temperatures. An extended period of freezing
temperatures could cause ruptured water pipes.
alert.instruction:
Monitor the latest forecasts and warnings for updates.

Avoid outside activities if possible. When outside, make sure you
wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and gloves.

Make frequent checks on older family, friends, and neighbors. Ensure
portable heaters are used correctly. Do not use generators or grills
inside.

alert.headline: Cold Weather Advisory issued January 22 at 2:43AM EST until January 24 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton; Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills as low as 20 to 25 below expected
Friday morning. Continued significant cold Friday and Friday night.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest, and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...From 1 AM Friday to 10 AM EST Saturday.

* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills approaching 25 below
zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30
minutes. Frostbite and hypothermia will occur if unprotected skin
is exposed to these temperatures.
alert.instruction:
Use caution while outdoors. Wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and
gloves. Keep pets indoors as much as possible and consider making
checks on older family, friends, and neighbors. Ensure portable
heaters are used correctly. Do not use generators or grills inside.
